We need to rein in spending, improve the efficiency of how we deliver key social programs, and get serious about our nation‚Äôs debt immediately.

The Fed waited too long to move on interest rates and Washington continues to spend too much money.  Now America is about to be hit with a double whammy. Higher interest rates and expensive debt payments.

Biden‚Äôs recently submitted budget for next year assumes interest on the debt will stay low because the White House assumes inflation will stay very very low. What the Federal Reserve is telling us today is that may NOT be the case.

With today‚Äôs #ratehike the Fed is finally taking action to address out-of-control inflation. The Fed and other wonks have been saying inflation was ‚Äútransitory.‚Äù I‚Äôve discussed the need to address the Feds massive balance sheet since Dec. of 2020. https://t.co/NntTAAPVfE

Many economists don‚Äôt think it will get this bad, but if it rises to even 5%, the cost will be $1 Trillion in annual payments.  For comparison, the Federal Government spends ~$1.2 Trillion per year on Social Security and ~$1.4 Trillion on Medicare.
Why is there a risk debt payments will balloon?  In the 1980‚Äôs when inflation was last at ~8%, average interest on the debt was ~10%.
If we were paying interest on the debt of 10% last year, the cost of our interest on the debt would be ~$2 Trillion. Almost the cost Social Security and Medicare combined.
Our current Treasury debt has different maturity dates and the impact will not be felt immediately. But it will be felt soon. It will increase over time as new debt is issued. https://t.co/7i8r4IqXyX

Following today‚Äôs #FederalReserve action, the interest on the debt went up 0.5%. This doesn‚Äôt sound like a lot but it means we will now have an additional interest payment of about ~$100B or the cost of all federal housing programs.

Today the #Fed raised rates 0.5%. This is going to significantly increase the cost of paying for our National Debt of ~$30 Trillion. 
 
Aüßµon the looming economic crisis of ballooning debt payments.
